awd_titl_txt: Planning Grant: Collaborative Research: I/UCRC for Building Reliable Advances and Innovation in Neurotechnology (BRAIN)
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will bring together teams from Arizona State University and University of Houston in collaboration with industry partners to establish a research center, called BRAIN (Building Reliable Advances and Innovation in Neurotechnology) that will overcome several innovation challenges in neurotechnology: 1) The pace of innovation exceeds the rate of evaluation for acceptable performance; 2) Standards and regulatory science for rigorous validation of safety, efficacy, and long-term reliability are missing; 3) Lack of open access to technologies and synergistic collaborations impede transfer of novel technologies to the market; and 4) Current technologies are costly, limiting their utility in enhancing treatment and overcoming physical disabilities. In addition, the BRAIN Center, through the efforts of the Education/Outreach coordinator, will work to rectify under-representation in the science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) fields by broadening new participation and retaining current participants in STEM through 1) newly initiated K-12 outreach programs that expose aspiring STEM participants to innovative neurotechnologies, 2) undergraduate internship program within the Center that targets specific student organizations (e.g., Society of Mexican-American Engineers and Scientists, Society of Women Engineers), and 3) focusing on problems in the neurological space that affect underrepresented groups disproportionately. 

The Center's vision is a synergistic, interdisciplinary approach to the development and validation of affordable patient-centered technologies, and use of those technologies in understanding neural systems. BRAIN will leverage expertise in neural, cognitive and rehabilitation engineering, robotics, clinical testing, and reverse-translational research at Arizona State University (ASU) and the University of Houston (UH) to (a) enhance the rate of development and empirical validation of new technologies through partnerships with industry leaders and other strategic partners; (b) develop standards and test technologies in human and non-human models using a multi-scale approach ranging from single neurons to organismal systems; (c) characterize novel and innovative technologies such as biosensors and quantitative analysis tools for systems and behaviors; (d) evaluate the impact of these technologies on quality of life; and (e) reduce the cost burden of neural technologies on hospitals and families.

por.por_cntn:
Age-­related diseases are becoming the leading cause of disability in the US. Millions of adults live with neurological disorders, limb loss from amputation or paralysis from spinal cord injury. Traumatic brain injury can have lifelong effects on cognitive­motor function significantly decreasing quality and length of life. We face a critical need for technology that can more effectively address the care and rehabilitation needs of these patients. The Centers for Disease Control estimate that the prevention of new injuries and development of novel therapies could save ~$400B on future lifetime costs. However, innovation in neurotechnology faces several challenges: 1) The pace of innovation exceeds the rate of evaluation for acceptable performance? 2) Standards and regulatory science for the rigorous validation of safety, efficacy, and long­term reliability are missing? 3) Lack of open access to technologies and synergistic collaborations impede the transfer of novel technologies to the market? and 4) Current technologies are costly, limiting their utility in enhancing treatment and overcoming physical disabilities.

The Planning Grant “Collaborative Research: I/UCRC for Building Reliable Advances and Innovation in Neurotechnology (BRAIN)" was an instrumental first step toward creating an university/industry collaborative research center that can effectively address the above challenges. The center pursues a synergistic and interdisciplinary approach to the development and validation of affordable patient­-centered technologies, and use of those technologies in understanding neural systems. BRAIN will leverage expertise in neural, cognitive and rehabilitation engineering, robotics, clinical testing, and reverse­translational  research at the University of Houston (UH) and Arizona State University (ASU) to (a) enhance the rate of development and empirical validation of new technologies through partnerships with industry leaders and other strategic partners? (b) develop standards and technologies in human and non­human models, using a multi­scale approach ranging from single neurons to organismal systems? (c) characterize novel and innovative technologies such as biosensors and quantitative analysis tools for systems and behaviors? (d) evaluate the impact of these technologies on quality of life? and (e) reduce the cost burden of neurotechnologies on hospitals and families. The meeting supported by the Planning Grant enabled the PIs to successfully recruit 13 prospective members from leaders in the neurotechnology industry, major healthcare providers and clinical research centers, and foundations. An I/UCRC proposal is currently under review by the National Science Foundation.

Intellectual Merit

BRAIN will leverage UH­ASU’s unique concentration of researchers and innovative R&D ecosystems with industrial partnerships to design, develop, test, and characterize neural technologies that can effectively transform the lives of disabled individuals. The Center will investigate all levels of neural function to enhance not only current technologies but also understanding of the mechanisms underlying neurological disease and injury. We will take a multi­scale, multi­modal, and multi­disciplinary approach to understanding all aspects of human neural function, and to deploying technologies treating human disability. The Center will bring a broad range of expertise spanning the spectrum of mental, neural, and physical disabilities across the human lifespan, and intervention techniques including peripheral nerve implants, cortical arrays, and noninvasive solutions. Center’s members will have direct access to and expertise in research (from single cells to system approaches) and capabilities to test both human and non­human models. We have recruited leading companies in the neurotechnology, robotics and clinical spaces, and will continue to engage other potential partners in the BRAIN center.

Broader Impacts

BRAIN will rectify underrepresentation  in science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) fields by broadening new participation and retaining current participants in STEM through 1) new K­12 outreach programs that expose aspiring STEM students to innovative neurotechnologies, 2) undergraduate internship programs that targets specific student organizations (e.g., the Society of Mexican­American Engineers and Scientists, the Society of Women Engineers), and 3) focusing on problems in the neurological space that affect underrepresented groups disproportionately. ASU (located in Phoenix with Hispanic populations at twice the national average) and UH (Hispanic ­serving institution) are uniquely suited to increasing the representation of students of Hispanic descent in STEM disciplines. BRAIN will become an innovative neurotechnology hub for the Southwest creating a pipeline from discoveries to solutions while enabling talented students, scientists and engineers in the region to take their innovation to the next level and solve the greatest unmet medical and health care needs of our time.
